description: From Middle English verite, from Anglo-Norman verité or Middle French verité, from Old French verité, from Latin vēritās, from the adjective vērus (“true”).

entries.meaning: Truth, fact or reality, especially an enduring religious or ethical truth; veracity.
A true statement; an established doctrine.
examples: Absolutist verities were not only being challenged in more systematic and more daring forms than hitherto; the parameters of political debate were also being widened by both government and its critics.
